lexUnit.name: wink.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: close and open one eye quickly, typically as a signal of affection or greeting or to convey a message.

sentence.text: He caught Carol 's eye , and winked .
His left eye winked solemnly .
She opened her eyes again , winked at Thérèse .
The baby doll 's blue glass eyes winked at her .
He winked an eye at his companion and said to Frankie : ` Been to the pictures , have we , son ? "
Seeing my disappointment he winked an eye and said , ` Well , I must admit that it makes a good story " .
She was reassured when he suddenly looked down at her and winked appreciatively .
Well , she said , you know what commercial travellers are , and laughed and winked .
Yanto winked at Billy , who grabbed his mug and said , ` Okay , drink up , anything for a quiet life . "
Keach winked at her .
Shepherd winked at him .
He winked at Toby and me , standing together in the audience which had gathered round .
Nurse bodkin winked in delight as she waltzed past .
Antonio winked in Stephen 's direction .
David winked over Josh 's head .
He winked good-naturedly over the rim of his glass .
He looked over and winked back .
Billy 's wide mouth stretched into a grin as he winked back .
She winked wickedly back at him , slyly insinuating that she would satisfy all his wants .
She threw him a kiss as he winked up at her , smiling .
He nodded and winked exaggeratedly .
Johnny Dee winked lewdly , and he and Kelley shuffled backwards through the doorway and were gone .
Dennis winked unpleasantly as they walked back to the stables .
She glared at him and he winked wickedly .
The mechanics wink and whistle and smoke aromatic cigars .
He tried to wink but , naturally , failed .
Then he 'll wink and walk off , or slide over on his seat , looking nonchalant .
